text: I never people asked me about my review
of ayaan Hirsi Ally's book the gadfly
and really more broadly about my
perceptions of Islam especially visibly
the role of women I tend to think that
Islam is a little bit like the
proverbial elephant to the blind men
touch and it really depends on what part
you encounter in terms of what frames
your view of Islam as a whole you know
if you go to Yemen Afghanistan the
tribal areas in Pakistan then you see
Islam as the justification for women not
being sent to school for not being
allowed up and out of the house without
the husbands mission for all kinds of
poor child marriage for all kinds of
behaviors that we truly regard as as
barbaric on the other hand if you go to
Bangladesh for example then you see a
country where there are now more girls
in high school then there were boys I go
to Indonesia which has had a woman
president and it it seems to me that my
reading of history is that when the
Prophet Muhammad arrived on the scene he
had quite liberated views about the role
of women but then it equally seems to me
that in subsequent centuries you had
much more conservative outlooks on the
role of women become ossified and that
indeed
you had this sanctified notion of women
as subordinates that that became
ossified in in much of the Islamic world
and more conservative parts are still
having to deal with that but I think
it's really dangerous to make
generalizations about a religion as vast
and disparate as Islam is today
